title: 104_hr892
content: The "Independent Counsel Accountability and Reform Act of 1995" amends Section 599 of title 28, United States Code, changing the name to "Accountability and Reform Act of 1995". It also establishes the basis for preliminary investigations. The "Independent Counsel Accountability and Reform Act of 1995" amends Section 591 of title 28, United States Code by specifying credible sources for specific information and changing "may have" to "has". The "Independent Counsel Accountability and Reform Act of 1995" amends Section 591 of title 28, United States Code by specifying credible sources for specific information and changing "may have" to "has". It also sets a 15-day time period for the Attorney General to determine the need for a preliminary investigation. The Attorney General must close the matter if there is no evidence of violation within a 15-day period. If evidence is found, a preliminary investigation will be initiated. If unable to determine, a preliminary investigation will still commence after the 15-day period. Section 592(c)(2) of title 28, United States Code is amended regarding the receipt of additional information. Section 592(c)(2) of title 28, United States Code is amended to require specific information from a credible source for additional information. SEC. 4. PROSECUTORIAL JURISDICTION OF INDEPENDENT COUNSEL. Prosecutorial jurisdiction under title 28, United States Code, is amended to specify limitations to alleged criminal law violations and related matters when the Attorney General requests the appointment of an independent counsel. The amendment to prosecutorial jurisdiction under title 28, United States Code, ensures that an independent counsel appointed by the Attorney General has the authority to fully investigate and prosecute alleged violations of criminal law, including perjury and obstruction of justice. The amendment to prosecutorial jurisdiction under title 28, United States Code allows an independent counsel appointed by the Attorney General to investigate and prosecute criminal violations such as perjury, obstruction of justice, destruction of evidence, and intimidation of witnesses. SEC. 5. AUTHORITIES AND DUTIES OF INDEPENDENT COUNSEL. The Administrator of General Services must provide office space for independent counsels within a Federal building, unless other arrangements are more cost-effective. Amendments ensure compliance with Department of Justice policies by requiring independent counsels to adhere to them at all times. The code is amended to require adherence to Department of Justice policies at all times and to expand the scope of enforcement of criminal laws. Prior amendments to section 594(f) of title 28, United States Code, are repealed. Additionally, limitations on expenditures are imposed on section 594. No funds may be expended for the operation of any office of independent counsel after the end of the 2-year period after its establishment, except if specifically authorized by an appropriations Act. SEC. 6. REMOVAL, TERMINATION, AND PERIODIC REAPPOINTMENT OF INDEPENDENT COUNSEL. Section 596(a)(1) of title 28, United States Code, is amended to allow for the removal of an independent counsel for failure to comply with Department of Justice policies. Section 596(b)(2) is amended to give the court the authority to terminate an independent counsel's office at any time. The court may terminate an office of independent counsel at any time, on its own motion, upon the request of the Attorney General, or upon the petition of the subject of an investigation conducted by the independent counsel, if the petition is made more than 2 years after the appointment of the independent counsel. This can be done on the grounds that the investigation has been completed or substantially completed, and it would be appropriate for the Department of Justice to take over. The independent counsel may be terminated if the investigation is completed or not in the public interest. Monthly expenditures must be reported to specified committees. The independent counsel must report monthly expenditures to specified committees. The amendment regarding this reporting takes effect after the first month following the enactment of the Act. Additionally, there are provisions for the periodic reappointment of an independent counsel after two years. The independent counsel must report monthly expenditures to specified committees and there are provisions for the periodic reappointment of the counsel every two years if the office has not been terminated. The court will determine if the counsel should be reappointed based on their ability to carry out the duties of the office. The court will appoint a qualified person to carry out the duties of the office if the current independent counsel is deemed inappropriate. If the court fails to take action within 90 days after the 2-year period, the office of independent counsel will terminate. The Comptroller General of the United States will submit a report to Congress within 1 year of this Act's enactment, with recommendations to improve cost controls for independent counsel offices under chapter 40 of title 28, United States Code.
